ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained so much knowledge about the extensive history of ancient Mesopotamia and the surrounding areas. This course was inspiring and even caused me to do some outside research on many of the course topics on my own.
I learned a lot about Ancient Mesopotamia, and I feel like I got a good overview over each of its main time periods.

I learned about the history of ancient Mesopotamia and the Near East, from the first archeological evidence of civilization to the conquering of the land by the Persians and later Alexander the Great. The class goes in depth into the primary sources that inform what we know about ancient Mesopotamia. We learned about the culture, religion, warfare, politics, foreign relations and more.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:  very interesting readings and lectures.  Very passionate professor.  
Weaknesses:  Too much reading at times, would have loved a visual timeline of events, like a bit more structure to help me divide the history up in my head.
Sometimes the lectures didn't completely align with reading materials, but other than that it was very interesting and engaging.

Strengths: Professor Frahm is a great thinker and an expert in his field, and it's really fun to hear him think out loud about Mesopotamian history and different understandings. 
Professor and TA were easygoing and grading was lenient
Interesting readings which were a good complement to the lecture
Expectations were clear

Weaknesses:
Lectures could sometimes have too many tangents
Professor Frahm would sometimes try to get class participation but it never felt so natural, more like he was lecturing and then would just suddenly ask for thoughts without so much warning or something to base the question of comment off of
I think sometimes Professor Frahm would present tentative theories (especially around Biblical literature) as if they were conclusive

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, its an interesting course and a great survey in Ancient Mesopotamia.
Definitely! A great was to learn a lot of information about the beginning of civilization without too much depth.

Yes! You cover three thousand years of history, and although you don't go crazy in depth, you learn a meaningful amount about each major time period over these three thousand years, and you leave with a feeling like you really learned something. The workload is extremely manageable and Professor Frahm is a good, thoughtful guy.
Yes, the class is very interesting, and Eckhart Frahm is an expert on this subject. This class is a unique opportunity to learn about ancient history from one of the most knowledgeable in the field.
